urn:contentItem:63BY-SXC1-F0HF-84G2-00000-00TIME’S UP BRING CLIMATE CHANGE TO FOREFRONT2021-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:26ZLexisNexisYOUR LETTERSPg. A9TIME’S UP BRING CLIMATE CHANGE TO FOREFRONT

There is a responsibility that comes with being a voter, with being a global citizen, with being someone with hope for the future.

I heard someone say recently how frequently hope is used in passive sentences, to convey a desire, with no call to action and no required action of oneself.

But there is no hope for the future without action, which should be very apparent to anyone living in the Okanagan amidst heatwaves, drought and intense forest fire smoke, not to mention the risk of wildfire itself.

We should all be holding elected officials accountable for the constant errors they are currently making in not prioritising the environment and mitigating climate change in every decision they make.

If MP Mel Arnold or MLA Greg Kyllo have a public speaking engagement, or indeed any public appearance, and they’re not talking about climate change, they should be ashamed, and anyone concerned about the future of their children and grandchildren should be making that clear.

If they are not bringing these issues to the forefront of their own political parties’ agendas and campaigns, then they are failing doubly.

We have a responsibility as citizens to make sure public officials at all levels know that the environment should be their first priority, and that other ‘priorities’ to keep economies strong and development moving should be centred around the real and finite resources upon which our very lives depend.

urn:contentItem:6350-M6M1-F0HF-80N6-00000-00Four Rivers Co-op collecting monetary donations for wildfire relief efforts2021-07-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A5Four Rivers Co-op collecting monetary donations for wildfire relief efforts

Four Rivers Co-op is stepping up as wildfires sweep across B.C. The co-operative has activated its Fire Relief Fund at all locations throughout its trading area, including Vanderhoof, Prince George, Quesnel, 100 Mile House, Houston and Terrace.

Customers can make a cash donation for the Red Cross that Four Rivers Co-op will match.

“We believe it’s the right thing to do,” said general manager Allan Bieganski.

“This was very sim-ilar to what we did in 2017 and 2018.”

Residents quickly opened their hearts and wallets as destructive fires resulted in the evacuation of more than 65,000 people over the summer of 2017.

Four Rivers Co-operative marketing coordinator Renee Dick said $20,056 was matched, resulting in a donation of $40,113 to the Red Cross.

In 2018 as wildfires hit closer to home near communities such as Fraser Lake and Fort St. James, Dick said members donated $6,928 that was once again matched for a total donation to the Red Cross of $13,857.

“It’s an amazing program and one that we’re really proud of,” she said.

Bieganski said by working together during what’s appearing to be a terrible forest fire season, he is hopeful British Columbians will be able to pull through as they had in 2017 and 2018.

urn:contentItem:64CF-R3T1-JD2C-J3TH-00000-00‘Critical’ work planned for Canim hillside2021-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:26ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A5‘Critical’ work planned for Canim hillside

Fire mitigation efforts in the South Canim Lake area impacted by a large wildfire this past summer are being coordinated by forestry officials and contractors.

Cariboo Regional District director Margo Wagner, who represents Forest Grove-Canim Lake, told community residents in an email that she had met with forestry officials and mitigation along the steep hillside above South Canim Lake Road was a main priority within the South Cariboo fire centre.

Canim Lake band members will be clearing the logs that were cut to make a firebreak during the wildfire in order to give access for the further mitigation work, she said.

Consultants and contractors have been hired to carry out the work Wagner describes as “critical” on the hillside, which is aimed at being completed prior to the 2022 spring freshet.

“This work includes creating 65 water bars to allow water to flow across the guards, six cross-ditches on the north and west flanks of there and cleaning and repairing two stream crossings,” Wagner said. “Some dry seeding will also be done along the flank to stabilize the soil.”

The work is not weather-dependent, she said, and if the ground is too frozen to complete it, she was told by officials that “they will hire bigger equipment.”

Wagner explained the work over the winter is an effort to restore parts of the hillside that were disrupted during this summer’s fire, which burned more than 2,500 hectares throughout July.

“When they put these fire breaks in to try to control the forest fire, it messes up all the natural drainage systems on the slope,” she said. “The mitigation work after a fire is to put those back in place so the water flows where it’s supposed to and doesn’t create a new path with a potential for mudslides.”

Given that this year’s fire burned so far down the hillside and closer to residential areas, Wagner said she “pushed really hard” for this work to get underway before spring.

Letter to the editor:

Are we doomed because McDonald's may be coming to Kimberley?

My comments are based on the three letters that appeared in the Kimberley Bulletin, March 28/23.

With respect to the contributors, they all make some reasonable points and explanations. It is evident that whatever the city decides, not everyone is going to be happy, and that is a given in most cases.

McDonald's may leave its mark on the citizens and visitors in Kimberley, but is it the end of the world or the beginning of Kimberley's demise? If anything it could be the start of new growth, which the city does need.

The mayor is right; once a large or small company comes, others will follow. But to think they will all have negative health impacts could be a stretch. If, as stated "We can choose to welcome the businesses that will move us toward a healthy future we all want." It is obvious that "we" will not necessarily include all.

Are the comments about healthy eating valid? Of course they are. Is there anything positive about eating at a fast food place? Actually there are a few:

It gives you the option to eat something instead of skipping a meal.

Helps you to manage a schedule more effectively.

The industry provides you with the nutritional information of each item.

There are more healthy choices at fast food restaurants today than ever before.

The fast food industry provides a significant economic boost to most communities.

It is an affordable way to experience new or different food choices.

On the negative side:

It can have a negative impact on your skeletal system over time. But so can driving a car too fast.

Eating fast food can lead to issues with edema, bloating, and swelling.

People who eat at fast food restaurants underestimate their calorie intake.

Fast food can have an adverse impact on the cardiovascular and digestive systems.

It is true that almost any other option is a better choice than fast food for your regular eating habits because of the high levels of fat, sugar, and salt found in most items. But if used with moderation, getting daily, moderate exercise, and eliminating the sugary sodas from the equation, the impacts of eating at a fast food place can be reduced.

Another point to seriously consider is, don't you think we should give parents credit for looking after their kids and making choices to keep them healthy and active. Nowadays it seems if it isn't endorsed by some health expert we shouldn't be doing it.

As far as the environmental impact of "another" gas station let's consider a few facts. The primary cause of the global diversity crisis is human induced alterations and loss of natural habitat. Housing development also has a detrimental effect to adjacent green spaces or protected areas. Most would probably agree housing is an issue, not just in Kimberley but Canada wide and it isn't going away anytime soon. But housing development isn't a panacea to the problem.

If anything, housing development increases impervious surfaces and risk of fire, which in turn spreads pollutants, changes nutrients and biological cycles. Changing land use and removing natural land cover introduces barriers to wildlife movements. Wow! Does that mean more or fewer deer in Kimberley?

When it's all over it does add to the merits of living in Kimberley. But I forget to mention, first you have to cut all the trees down to make room for development, and then spend money to grow more trees, and then be afraid of a forest fire. And worse, if all the firefighters are at McDonald's – you lose everything.

On a more serious note: Like many I have concerns about new development in Kimberley, not with hampering growth but with safety. As Kimberley grows, and it will, there needs to be serious consideration for traffic signals on the Highway intersection, between the Maysville School / proposed Day Care, activity at the area, Fire Hall and new development in the area. That particular intersection is an accident looking to happen. And it will.

Final comments. Nowadays everything seems to be based on a new study. Not long ago fast food places where blamed for obesity, later another study said it wasn't, and the list goes on. Every study is right until another study proves it wrong.

The kids of today have the solution: A new study states: Kids would rather learn from smart robots than less smart humans.

Ron Kerr

I am grateful for the input of the physicians and others who wrote in to the Kimberley Bulletin. Perspective is important to make an informed decision.

I live in Marysville and am one of those folks who chose Kimberley precisely because it was not a fast food town. The unique choice to have quality options was a factor for me. And I like the fresh air. Not only would the pollution be a problem, but the smell would also be there.

A question that should be asked is "What will it cost Kimberley if this is approved?" To my thinking, it would reduce the appeal of a relaxed atmosphere as fast food is fast culture. That's not why I am here. I can also imagine the increased amount of garbage that would have to be dealt with. If the place would be open until late evening, it will also cost the quiet and dark sky community feel.

Questions I would like to know the answer starts with how many people have asked for a McDonalds to be in Marysville or anywhere in Kimberley? Were citizens the ones who approached the city or was it a corporation? I had heard one of the arguments was creating about 60 jobs. I wonder how that number came about and what kind of jobs they would be. Part time without benefits? More cars for transporting to and from home?

What is the cost of cleaning up the gas station when it is no longer in use? How is the business owner/developer securing funding for any environmental issues?

I believe this needs to be discussed with the whole community and we need to hear from those who work with children. Now that the daycare is going to be built at Marysville Elementary, the perspective of the health and well-being of future Kimberley citizens deserves to be championed.

Respectfully,

Emma Bourassa

Dear Neighbors:

LIVE LIFE. PASS IT ON.

Did you know April is Organ Donation Awareness Month and April 7th is known as Green Shirt Day? Green Shirt Day is intended to raise awareness of organ donation and promote donor registration across Canada. This day was prompted by the parents of Logan Boulet. Logan was one of the 16 young hockey players on the Humboldt Broncos killed in a bus crash in 2018. He passed on April 7 and six people received lifesaving organs. You can find out more about Logan Boulet and Green Shirt Day here: www.greenshirtday.ca

Did you know that about 4,100 Canadians are waiting for a lifesaving organ transplant and each year hundreds of Canadians die while on transplant waiting lists? This included ten British Columbians in 2022. An unfortunate reality is that 90 per cent of Canadians say they support organ donation, yet only 32 per cent have actually registered their decision. So, as one of the 101 beneficiaries of a BC donor liver last year I feel compelled to add my voice to those promoting awareness of the donor registry.

Registering to be an organ donor is a simple act but a significant one: one organ donor can save up to eight lives and a tissue donor can improve the lives of up to 75 patients. If you support organ donation but haven't yet registered, please consider doing it right now at this location: www.transplant.bc.ca/organ-donation/register-as-an-organ-donor

It's been 14 months since my surgery. I'm cancer-free and I can thank an anonymous donor for that. At some point that person thought it important enough to take two minutes out of their day to register their donation decision. Thank you.

Rob MacDonald

urn:contentItem:63BY-SXC1-F0HF-84SC-00000-00OUR of GLIMPSES PAST2021-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15OUR of GLIMPSES PAST

130 years ago:Kootenay Star, Aug. 15, 1891 Frank Bourne, of Bourne Bros. General Store, and Morgan David, employee of the Revelstoke Lumber Co., made the first known ascent of Mount Mackenzie. The trip took them 48 hours, and they marveled at the abundant alpine wildflowers and the stunning views.

120 years ago:Revelstoke Herald, Aug. 10, 1901 Dr. McLean came back from Ferguson last night bringing with him J. McTaggart, a miner, who was injured by the premature explosion of a shot at the Metropolitan claim last Wednesday. Owing to some misunderstanding, the shot was fired before he left the lower workings of the mine and blew him completely off the face of the mountain, rolling him down some 300ft.

110 years ago:Mail-Herald, Aug. 9, 1911 The Vernon Hotel on Douglas Street was been taken over by Mrs. Hanbury and was to be changed into a first class rooming and apartment house. The entire building was being thoroughly renovated and refurnished, including the installation of steam heat in every room.

100 years ago:Revelstoke Review, Aug. 11, 1921 The new automobile ambulance for the Queen Victoria Hospital was finished and was to be in readiness for calls by the end of the week. The ambulance was mostly built in Revelstoke by locals. It was put together at the Revelstoke Garage and the body was built on a Ford chassis.

90 years ago:Revelstoke Review, Aug. 14, 1931 According to Arthur O. Wheeler, honorary president of the Alpine Club of Canada and Canadian representative of the International Commission on glaciers, general retreat of the ice fields of the Rocky Mountains is ample evidence that Canadian winters are becoming milder. Mr. Wheeler declared that the Robson glacier has retreated 790 feet since he made initial observations in 1911. His investigations in the past week have shown a remarkable change.

80 years ago:Revelstoke Review, Aug. 14, 1941 Four cars of ice were brought to Revelstoke the week before last, when the hot weather of recent weeks depleted the stock of the local plant of Inland Ice and Cold Storage Co. At the peak of the heat wave, the local plant dispensed 100 tons a day to the CPR for air conditioning and refrigeration purposes.

70 years ago:Revelstoke Review, Aug. 9, 1951 According to federal surveyors, the Big Bend section of the Trans-Canada Highway between Revelstoke and Golden may be re-routed as the area could be utilized as a water storage basin for the production of paper. It is believed that it would result in a considerably shorter highway being built between the two municipalities if the survey shows promising results.

60 years ago:Revelstoke Review, Aug. 10, 1961 The heavy pull of grey-blue smoke hanging over the city and area Sunday afternoon and evening was the result of a forest fire in the Lytton dis-trict. Smoke drifting for hundreds of miles following a forest fire is not unusual.

50 years ago:Revelstoke Review, Aug. 12, 1971 Kel Collins, mine superintendent for Mount Copeland Mine, spoke at a Rotary meeting, and told the members that the min had recovered 1.23 million pounds of molybdenum metal in fourteen months of production. The mine, located high on Mount Copeland, was then the highest mine in the world.

40 years ago:Revelstoke Review, Aug. 12, 1981 Clara Lim retired from Vancouver General Hospital after 30 years of service as a nurse, rising to the position of Director of Nursing at the hospital. Clara Lim was born and raised in Revelstoke, and was one of ten children of early residents Wong Kwong and Yee Von Kwong, who ran a laundry where the Senior Citizens Centre is now located.

30 years ago:Revelstoke Times, Aug. 14, 1991 Canadian musician Bryan Adams performed in Centennial Park at Revelstoke to a crowd of about 11,000 people. The performance was part of Music 91, a province-wide celebration of music. Adams was chosen as the performer for the Revelstoke concert, with Chrissy Steele appearing as the opening act.

Dear Neighbors:

LIVE LIFE. PASS IT ON.

Did you know April is Organ Donation Awareness Month and April 7th is known as Green Shirt Day? Green Shirt Day is intended to raise awareness of organ donation and promote donor registration across Canada. This day was prompted by the parents of Logan Boulet. Logan was one of the 16 young hockey players on the Humboldt Broncos killed in a bus crash in 2018. He passed on April 7 and six people received lifesaving organs. You can find out more about Logan Boulet and Green Shirt Day here: www.greenshirtday.ca

Did you know that about 4,100 Canadians are waiting for a lifesaving organ transplant and each year hundreds of Canadians die while on transplant waiting lists? This included ten British Columbians in 2022. An unfortunate reality is that 90 per cent of Canadians say they support organ donation, yet only 32 per cent have actually registered their decision. So, as one of the 101 beneficiaries of a BC donor liver last year I feel compelled to add my voice to those promoting awareness of the donor registry.

Registering to be an organ donor is a simple act but a significant one: one organ donor can save up to eight lives and a tissue donor can improve the lives of up to 75 patients. If you support organ donation but haven't yet registered, please consider doing it right now at this location: www.transplant.bc.ca/organ-donation/register-as-an-organ-donor

It's been 14 months since my surgery. I'm cancer-free and I can thank an anonymous donor for that. At some point that person thought it important enough to take two minutes out of their day to register their donation decision. Thank you.

Rob MacDonald

Instead they're running most of the time, polluting the air you breathe2023-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:26ZLexisNexisNEWS/CANADA/ONTARIOPg. 1Ontario gas plants were supposed to run only during peak periods. Instead they're running most of the time, polluting the air you breatheMarco Chown Oved Climate Change Reporter, Andrew Bailey Data Analyst


In a pink shirt and a satin blue tie, a representative of the company that wanted to build a new gas plant sat down in front of his webcam and started his presentation, the sound of his voice only slightly desynchronized with his picture.

Projected on large screens in city council chambers, and watched online by citizens concerned about air pollution and carbon emissions, he reassured everyone that the generator would only operate during periods of peak electricity demand - "two per cent of the time."



"It really serves more like an insurance policy for the electricity system," said Kelly Lail, vice-president of business development at Capital Power.

Windsor City Council endorsed the project, one of three new gas plants and six upgrades the Ontario government has announced over the past year in an effort to meet growing demand for electricity.

These "peaker plants" are essential to the reliability of the provincial electricity grid, authorities say, because they can be fired up whenever electricity demand rises beyond what non-emitting sources, such as nuclear, hydro and renewables, can provide.

An investigation by the Toronto Star has found, however, that many of the province's gas plants are operating far more often than their proponents say, effectively transforming them from rarely used peaker plants into baseload power plants that run almost all the time.

As a result, Ontario's clean electricity is getting far dirtier, producing millions of tonnes of climate-destabilizing carbon emissions and spewing toxic pollutants into the air in some of the most densely populated urban areas in the province.

"This will make air pollution worse, make climate pollution worse, and negatively affect Ontario's competitive advantage in having a clean grid," said Ontario Green Party Leader Mike Schreiner.

"And on top of that, because fossil gas is so much more expensive than solar, wind and water power, it's going to increase our electricity bills."

A deep dive into hour-by-hour generation data shows the province's 12 biggest gas plants operated nearly 12 hours a day, on average, every day this year.

The three GTA gas plants were turned on even more. The Portlands Energy Centre in Toronto, the Goreway Power Station in Brampton and the Halton Hills Generating Station have been in production for an average of 14 hours and 40 minutes a day.

This summer, when electricity demand was higher, the GTA plants were fired up more than 19 hours a day.

The Portlands plant, located on the waterfront in the heart of downtown Toronto, ran the most: nearly 21 hours a day, all summer long.

"I'm shocked how much these plants are running," said Keith Stewart, an energy strategist with Greenpeace Canada. "When they were being built, we were told they were supposed to only run around five per cent of the time. And they were just there to provide that last bit of security for the electricity system."

"Now they're actually the workhorses of the system, which is not what was promised."

It's been almost a decade since the last smog day in Toronto, so long that some may have forgotten about air quality concerns. But after a summer when the GTA was blanketed in forest fire smoke and children were kept indoors some days, the implications of running gas plants in the heart of Canada's biggest city are doubly clear: they add to local air pollution while also making climate change worse.

This is one of the reasons why clean, non-emitting, renewable energy has been identified as a top priority for addressing climate change. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the International Energy Agency, the Canadian Energy Regulator, the federal government and Ontario's Independent Electricity System Operator (IESO) have all said that achieving net zero emissions will require an all but-complete phaseout of fossil fuel-generated electricity.

The federal government is in the process of regulating that all electricity nationwide must be net zero by 2035. Yet Ontario hasn't built any new wind or solar energy since Premier Doug Ford was first elected in 2018. And the electricity generators already on the grid are emitting more pollution and more carbon as peaker plants now run virtually non-stop.

"These peaker plants are being used more than originally intended and that's not by accident. It's by design. It's a result of choices that this government has made to turn its back on clean energy and to instead go whole hog into more fossil fuels, using these existing plants more, extending their contracts longer, and also seeking to build new plants to add even more gas to the grid," said Keith Brooks, programs director at Environmental Defence.

Energy Minister Todd Smith declined to be interviewed for this story. In an emailed statement, he said he has committed to a 100 per cent clean grid, though did not say when it would be achieved. In the meantime, the use of gas will continue.

"Natural gas generation is our insurance policy that guarantees the lights stay on and prices stay down as we continue to refurbish our nuclear fleet and build out new technologies," Smith said in a statement.

Capital Power, the company that owns and operates the gas plants in Windsor and Brampton, said the company's statement that the new Windsor plant would run two per cent of the time refers to its capacity factor, a measurement of the plant's production versus its theoretical maximum output.

This "was and remains accurate," said spokesperson Katherine Perron.

Brampton's Goreway plant, however, is being used two and a half times more than it used to be, she said, due to "ongoing demand growth and nuclear refurbishments."

"Facilities like Goreway are only dispatched when market demands and conditions require their support so that all Ontarians can keep their lights on," she added.

Darius Sokal, a spokesperson for Atura Power, a subsidiary of the publicly owned Ontario Power Generation that runs the Portlands and Halton Hills plants, said: "Natural gas plays a critical role in Ontario's clean electricity system by reliably and affordably generating power during high demand periods. We comply with all provincial and federal emission standards."

THE PLANT NO ONE WANTED

Dubbed "the mistake by the lake" by opponents before it was even constructed, the Portlands gas plant was never welcome in downtown Toronto.

Paula Fletcher, the city councillor who has represented the ward that hosts the plant since 2003, said residents had fought hard to shut down two incinerators in the area because the toxic emissions were making them sick. Only two years later, the province announced that a new gas plant would be built, promising the return of more air pollution.

"This community tried to say this is not the right place for this particular plant and you should probably do something a little more efficient," said Fletcher.

One alternative proposal, which was endorsed by City Council, included a co-generation plant housed in the old Hearn Generating Station, which would provide power as well as steam to feed into Enwave's district heating system for the office towers downtown.

But the province overruled the city and went ahead with the Portlands electricity-only plan.

It was one of a fleet of gas plants commissioned by Queen's Park in the 2000s to replace the coal plants that were being phased out. Gas was supposed to be cleaner, and thanks to a burgeoning solar and wind industry, the new gas plants would only have to run as backup during peak times.

"We were told at the beginning that, don't worry, it's hardly ever going to run. So there'll be a minimal amount of emissions, a minimal amount of (air pollution). You won't notice it," Fletcher said.

While burning natural gas does produce less toxic air pollution than coal, its climate impact is now understood to be just as bad, if not worse.

That's because natural gas is mostly methane, a potent greenhouse gas. So leaks are far worse for the climate than emissions from combustion. Numerous studies have shown that "fugitive" leaks along the natural gas system - from the well to the pipeline to the furnace or gas plant - are far higher than previously thought.

Even without fugitive emissions, the Portlands gas plant is the largest single source of greenhouse gas emissions in Toronto. Emissions from the plant rose from 188,000 tonnes in 2017 to 618,000 tonnes in 2021, according to the federal government's national inventory of emissions.

Repeated calls to shut it down, or simply prevent its expansion, have gone unheeded. Toronto City Council has voted no fewer than three times against the plant, including twice this year just before the province announced an upgrade that would increase its output by nine per cent (a public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 5).

"What started off as a bad idea has become a really terrible idea on Toronto's waterfront," said Fletcher. "Nobody's watching this story and it is of great concern."

In the meantime, the Portlands plant has quietly ramped up its production, so that this summer it was only off for an average of three hours a day.

Former mayor David Miller, who is now managing director of the C40 Centre for City Climate Policy and Economy, staunchly opposed the Portlands plant before it was built, saying it was the wrong technology in the wrong place.

"On an issue as serious as this, I take no pleasure in being right," he told the Star. "I think it was a failure of imagination. It's a failure environmentally. It's a failure economically."

"The best case scenario for this plant was that you spent $730 million to only run a couple of hours a day in the summer, which is a ludicrous waste of money.

"The worst case scenario is it's being used far more, causing airborne pollutants that are directly linked to asthma and other health hazards and worsening the climate crisis. Both of those are completely wrong outcomes from a public policy perspective. We knew better then. We certainly know better now."

AIR POLLUTION

In 2014, Ontario became the first jurisdiction in the world to phase out coal-fired electricity, putting the province out ahead in an area that has become the linchpin to international efforts to curb climate change. But the Liberal government of then-premier Dalton McGuinty didn't get rid of coal because of climate change. They did it because air pollution had become a public health issue.

Studies linking the coal plants to smog and smog to thousands of premature deaths persuaded the government of the day to start the transition to clean electricity.

Unfortunately, while the coal plants are gone, the health concerns have not gone away.

"There's growing evidence about the health impacts of gas fired electricity plants," said Dr. Samantha Green, a family doctor at St. Michael's Hospital and president of the Canadian Association of Physicians for the Environment (CAPE).

"While they might be better than coal, they still have a significant health impact."

Gas plants produce nitrogen oxides, particulate matter and ground-level ozone, the main ingredient in smog.

Medical studies Green shared with the Star showed a link between living close to a gas plant and the development of asthma in children, exacerbation of asthma in people who already have it, as well as increased likelihood of preterm birth and emergency department visits.

One study found measurable health impacts in people living as far as 20 km away from a natural gas plant.

Draw a 20 km circle around the Portlands gas plant and you'll include virtually everyone who lives in Toronto. Add two more circles around the Brampton and Halton Hills plants and you'll add almost all of Brampton, Mississauga and Oakville, not to mention Milton, Bolton and large swaths of Vaughan.

All told, that's at least 4.5 million people who are facing adverse health effects from the increased use of the gas plants.

"Certainly, the highest impacts are actually felt by the people who are in proximity. But I think we don't have an answer to the question: How far away do you have to live before you are safe?" said Green.

A 2014 city report found that air pollution is responsible for 1,300 premature deaths in Toronto each year. A 2021 Health Canada study pegged the number at 6,600 province-wide.

"I don't think people are aware of the health impact, frankly," said NDP MPP Peter Tabuns, who has represented the riding around the Portlands plant since 2006. "They were far more aware when coal was the issue because you could see it. It's not as visible now, but clearly it's having substantial health impacts."

A 2012 report prepared by the city's environment office found "pollutants such as ozone, nitrogen dioxides, and particulate matter are found at levels that are known to have an adverse impact on health," in the wards immediately adjacent to the Portlands Energy Centre. But modelling performed at the time concluded the gas plant contributed "only insignificantly" to nitrogen oxides levels.

Fletcher, the local councillor, said it's time for the city to test the air in downtown Toronto again, now that we know the plant is running 86 per cent of the time.

MORE GAS PLANTS, RUNNING MORE OFTEN

Last year, in response to the 34 municipalities that passed resolutions calling for the phaseout of gas power, the province's electricity system regulator put out a report plotting a path to complete decarbonization.

It was a disappointment to climate activists and renewable energy proponents alike.

According to the IESO, continued use of gas is necessary, and in fact, more is needed. Phasing out gas would require a colossal investment of $400 billion and would take more than 20 years to accomplish.

It's a conclusion that has been disputed by several other expert reports, including one from RBC, which said no new gas plants are needed to meet electricity demand.

The IESO's logic is that gas plants are one-of-a-kind.

"Ontario's natural gas fleet is capable of providing continuous, flexible energy year round and under all weather conditions, and there is currently no like-for-like replacement," the IESO's Pathways to Decarbonization report states.

No sooner was the report tabled than the provincial government put out a call for 1,500 megawatts of new gas generation.

Queen's Park also issued a call for grid-scale batteries, which can serve the same role as gas plants, but only for four hours at a time. (This means they could replace true peaker plants, but cannot fill the expanded role gas plants currently serve, running far longer.)

There's no indication that new renewable energy - wind and solar - will be built any time soon. Despite being the cheapest source of electricity in history, Ontario has opted to spend billions on a new generation of nuclear plants instead.

Despite this spring's announcements of both small and full-size nuclear plants, the province will still be facing a serious shortfall of generation when the Pickering nuclear plant shuts down - long before the new plants are ready.

And the plan is to make up that shortfall by using the gas plants even more.

Projections produced by the IESO show that gas plants provincewide, which currently operate just under six hours a day, will rapidly increase their runtime to more than 19 hours a day in 2026.

But these averages, which cover 47 gas plants, small and large, scattered across the province, mask the fact that three of the biggest gas plants, nestled among houses and businesses in the GTA, are already used far more.

BUSINESSES WANT CLEAN ELECTRICITY

This summer, the provincial government blanketed TV, radio and even YouTube with ads proclaiming "the future is electric."

The message celebrated the return of auto manufacturing to Ontario, in the form of an industry-wide transition to electric vehicles (EVs).

The economic boost provided by these blue collar jobs has been a bright spot for Ford's government, prompting a change in attitude toward EVs, which started out as an object of scorn, as the premier cancelled purchase subsidies and ripped out charging stations.

Part of the reason battery and EV plants are setting up in Ontario is because of the province's clean electricity, a legacy of the coal-phaseout.

That clean electricity advantage was cited by Ford at last year's opening of the EV delivery truck assembly line in Ingersoll. Energy Minister Todd Smith has routinely said clean electricity underpins Ontario's attractiveness to business investment.

But it's a head start that risks being squandered now that the province is leaning so heavily on gas.

"Companies want to be able to say that they're cutting their greenhouse gas emissions. And what is being done by the Ford government is a substantial ramp up," said the NDP's Tabuns.

"We're seeing Ontario on track to emissions that will wipe out 60 per cent of the greenhouse gas reduction impact from shutting down coal. It's as if we've gone through that whole exercise to reduce our carbon footprint, and they've decided to largely wipe it out."

Meanwhile, the federal government has tabled a draft of its Clean Electricity Regulations, which promise net-zero electricity nationwide by 2035.

While the federal regulations will allow for some natural gas to remain for "peaking" and "emergency backup" purposes, an independent analysis found that many of Ontario's plants were currently operating 10 times more than they would be allowed to under the new rules.

This leaves Ontario's gas plant expansion plan with serious issues to resolve, said Environmental Defence's Brooks.

The province is trying to convince power providers to build plants that may be illegal to operate in 12 years, he said, and in order to do so, they're offering guaranteed payment, even if the plants shut down. What's more, they're in a hurry, Brooks said, because it appears any plants built before 2025 will be grandfathered in and allowed to operate until 2045.

"Ontarians are getting a raw deal either way. Either we're getting more gas plants, more emissions and more contributions to climate change, or we're paying for gas plants that aren't even running, which is going to cost us," he said.

"Ontarians are going to be on the hook paying billions of dollars for plants that we really don't want, don't need and shouldn't be using in the climate crisis."

PUSHBACK

The call for new gas plants has been out for almost a year. But only three sites have been announced. Taken together, the three prospective plants would only provide about a third of the amount of new gas called for, leaving the province scrambling to attract more proposals.

Last month, there was another setback. Thorold, a community in Niagara Region, voted to reject a new plant in their community over air pollution concerns.

The Ford government has taken notice, conscious of the fact that community outrage against gas plants helped bring down one of his predecessors.

"There's a reason why people in Mississauga and Oakville fought against gas plants like a decade or more ago. And it wasn't because of climate change. It was because they were concerned about the impact to air quality in their communities," said Brooks.

Or as Don Morley, a lifelong resident of Thorold who lives beside the existing plant, said:

"It was difficult for me, but I figure I had no choice but to step up and voice a concern that affects all of us," he told city council before the vote.

"There are many victims out there. Victims I shouldn't say, but citizens that deserve better."

Marco Chown Oved is a Toronto-based reporter covering climate change for the Star. Reach him via email: moved@thestar.ca

"We were told at the beginning that, don't worry, it's hardly ever going to run. So there'll be a minimal amount of emissions, a minimal amount of (air pollution). You won't notice it," Fletcher said.

While burning natural gas does produce less toxic air pollution than coal, its climate impact is now understood to be just as bad, if not worse.

That's because natural gas is mostly methane, a potent greenhouse gas. So leaks are far worse for the climate than emissions from combustion. Numerous studies have shown that "fugitive" leaks along the natural gas system - from the well to the pipeline to the furnace or gas plant - are far higher than previously thought.

Even without fugitive emissions, the Portlands gas plant is the largest single source of greenhouse gas emissions in Toronto. Emissions from the plant rose from 188,000 tonnes in 2017 to 618,000 tonnes in 2021, according to the federal government's national inventory of emissions.

Repeated calls to shut it down, or simply prevent its expansion, have gone unheeded. Toronto City Council has voted no fewer than three times against the plant, including twice this year just before the province announced an upgrade that would increase its output by nine per cent (a public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 5).

"What started off as a bad idea has become a really terrible idea on Toronto's waterfront," said Fletcher. "Nobody's watching this story and it is of great concern."

In the meantime, the Portlands plant has quietly ramped up its production, so that this summer it was only off for an average of three hours a day.

Former mayor David Miller, who is now managing director of the C40 Centre for City Climate Policy and Economy, staunchly opposed the Portlands plant before it was built, saying it was the wrong technology in the wrong place.

"On an issue as serious as this, I take no pleasure in being right," he told the Star. "I think it was a failure of imagination. It's a failure environmentally. It's a failure economically."

"The best case scenario for this plant was that you spent $730 million to only run a couple of hours a day in the summer, which is a ludicrous waste of money.

"The worst case scenario is it's being used far more, causing airborne pollutants that are directly linked to asthma and other health hazards and worsening the climate crisis. Both of those are completely wrong outcomes from a public policy perspective. We knew better then. We certainly know better now."

AIR POLLUTION

In 2014, Ontario became the first jurisdiction in the world to phase out coal-fired electricity, putting the province out ahead in an area that has become the linchpin to international efforts to curb climate change. But the Liberal government of then-premier Dalton McGuinty didn't get rid of coal because of climate change. They did it because air pollution had become a public health issue.

Studies linking the coal plants to smog and smog to thousands of premature deaths persuaded the government of the day to start the transition to clean electricity.

Unfortunately, while the coal plants are gone, the health concerns have not gone away.

"There's growing evidence about the health impacts of gas fired electricity plants," said Dr. Samantha Green, a family doctor at St. Michael's Hospital and president of the Canadian Association of Physicians for the Environment (CAPE).

"While they might be better than coal, they still have a significant health impact."

Gas plants produce nitrogen oxides, particulate matter and ground-level ozone, the main ingredient in smog.

Medical studies Green shared with the Star showed a link between living close to a gas plant and the development of asthma in children, exacerbation of asthma in people who already have it, as well as increased likelihood of preterm birth and emergency department visits.

One study found measurable health impacts in people living as far as 20 km away from a natural gas plant.

Draw a 20 km circle around the Portlands gas plant and you'll include virtually everyone who lives in Toronto. Add two more circles around the Brampton and Halton Hills plants and you'll add almost all of Brampton, Mississauga and Oakville, not to mention Milton, Bolton and large swaths of Vaughan.

All told, that's at least 4.5 million people who are facing adverse health effects from the increased use of the gas plants.

"Certainly, the highest impacts are actually felt by the people who are in proximity. But I think we don't have an answer to the question: How far away do you have to live before you are safe?" said Green.

A 2014 city report found that air pollution is responsible for 1,300 premature deaths in Toronto each year. A 2021 Health Canada study pegged the number at 6,600 province-wide.

"I don't think people are aware of the health impact, frankly," said NDP MPP Peter Tabuns, who has represented the riding around the Portlands plant since 2006. "They were far more aware when coal was the issue because you could see it. It's not as visible now, but clearly it's having substantial health impacts."

A 2012 report prepared by the city's environment office found "pollutants such as ozone, nitrogen dioxides, and particulate matter are found at levels that are known to have an adverse impact on health," in the wards immediately adjacent to the Portlands Energy Centre. But modelling performed at the time concluded the gas plant contributed "only insignificantly" to nitrogen oxides levels.

Fletcher, the local councillor, said it's time for the city to test the air in downtown Toronto again, now that we know the plant is running 86 per cent of the time.

MORE GAS PLANTS, RUNNING MORE OFTEN

Last year, in response to the 34 municipalities that passed resolutions calling for the phaseout of gas power, the province's electricity system regulator put out a report plotting a path to complete decarbonization.

It was a disappointment to climate activists and renewable energy proponents alike.

According to the IESO, continued use of gas is necessary, and in fact, more is needed. Phasing out gas would require a colossal investment of $400 billion and would take more than 20 years to accomplish.

It's a conclusion that has been disputed by several other expert reports, including one from RBC, which said no new gas plants are needed to meet electricity demand.

The IESO's logic is that gas plants are one-of-a-kind.

"Ontario's natural gas fleet is capable of providing continuous, flexible energy year round and under all weather conditions, and there is currently no like-for-like replacement," the IESO's Pathways to Decarbonization report states.

No sooner was the report tabled than the provincial government put out a call for 1,500 megawatts of new gas generation.

Queen's Park also issued a call for grid-scale batteries, which can serve the same role as gas plants, but only for four hours at a time. (This means they could replace true peaker plants, but cannot fill the expanded role gas plants currently serve, running far longer.)

There's no indication that new renewable energy - wind and solar - will be built any time soon. Despite being the cheapest source of electricity in history, Ontario has opted to spend billions on a new generation of nuclear plants instead.

And the plan is to make up that shortfall by using the gas plants even more.

Projections produced by the IESO show that gas plants provincewide, which currently operate just under six hours a day, will rapidly increase their runtime to more than 19 hours a day in 2026.

But these averages, which cover 47 gas plants, small and large, scattered across the province, mask the fact that three of the biggest gas plants, nestled among houses and businesses in the GTA, are already used far more.

This summer, the provincial government blanketed TV, radio and even YouTube with ads proclaiming "the future is electric."

The message celebrated the return of auto manufacturing to Ontario, in the form of an industry-wide transition to electric vehicles (EVs).

The economic boost provided by these blue collar jobs has been a bright spot for Ford's government, prompting a change in attitude toward EVs, which started out as an object of scorn, as the premier cancelled purchase subsidies and ripped out charging stations.

Part of the reason battery and EV plants are setting up in Ontario is because of the province's clean electricity, a legacy of the coal-phaseout.

What's more, they're in a hurry, Brooks said, because it appears any plants built before 2025 will be grandfathered in and allowed to operate until 2045.

"Ontarians are getting a raw deal either way. Either we're getting more gas plants, more emissions and more contributions to climate change, or we're paying for gas plants that aren't even running, which is going to cost us," he said.

Projected on large screens in city council chambers, and watched online by citizens concerned about air pollution and carbon emissions, he reassured everyone that the generator would only operate during periods of peak electricity demand - "two per cent of the time."



"It really serves more like an insurance policy for the electricity system," said Kelly Lail, vice-president of business development at Capital Power.

Windsor city council endorsed the project, one of three new gas plants and six upgrades the Ontario government has announced over the past year in an effort to meet growing demand for electricity.

These "peaker plants" are essential to the reliability of the provincial electricity grid, authorities say, because they can be fired up whenever electricity demand rises beyond what non-emitting sources, such as nuclear, hydro and renewables, can provide.

An investigation by the Toronto Star has found, however, that many of the province's gas plants are operating far more often than their proponents say, effectively transforming them from rarely used peaker plants into baseload power plants that run almost all the time.

As a result, Ontario's clean electricity is getting far dirtier, producing millions of tonnes of climate-destabilizing carbon emissions and spewing toxic pollutants into the air in some of the most densely populated urban areas in the province.

"This will make air pollution worse, make climate pollution worse, and negatively affect Ontario's competitive advantage in having a clean grid," said Ontario Green Party Leader Mike Schreiner.

"And on top of that, because fossil gas is so much more expensive than solar, wind and water power, it's going to increase our electricity bills," Schreiner said.

A deep dive into hour-by-hour generation data shows the province's 12 biggest gas plants operated nearly 12 hours a day, on average, every day this year.

The three GTA gas plants were turned on even more. The Portlands Energy Centre in Toronto, the Goreway Power Station in Brampton and the Halton Hills Generating Station have been in production for an average of 14 hours and 40 minutes a day.

This summer, when electricity demand was higher, the GTA plants were fired up more than 19 hours a day.

The Portlands plant, located on the waterfront in the heart of downtown Toronto, ran the most: nearly 21 hours a day, all summer long.

Instead they're running most of the time, polluting the air you breathe2023-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:26ZLexisNexisNEWS/CANADA/ONTARIOPg. 1Ontario gas plants were supposed to run only during peak periods. Instead they're running most of the time, polluting the air you breatheMarco Chown Oved Climate Change Reporter, Andrew Bailey Data Analyst


In a pink shirt and a satin blue tie, a representative of the company that wanted to build a new gas plant sat down in front of his webcam and started his presentation, the sound of his voice only slightly desynchronized with his picture.

Projected on large screens in city council chambers, and watched online by citizens concerned about air pollution and carbon emissions, he reassured everyone that the generator would only operate during periods of peak electricity demand - "two per cent of the time."



"It really serves more like an insurance policy for the electricity system," said Kelly Lail, vice-president of business development at Capital Power.

Windsor City Council endorsed the project, one of three new gas plants and six upgrades the Ontario government has announced over the past year in an effort to meet growing demand for electricity.

These "peaker plants" are essential to the reliability of the provincial electricity grid, authorities say, because they can be fired up whenever electricity demand rises beyond what non-emitting sources, such as nuclear, hydro and renewables, can provide.

An investigation by the Toronto Star has found, however, that many of the province's gas plants are operating far more often than their proponents say, effectively transforming them from rarely used peaker plants into baseload power plants that run almost all the time.

As a result, Ontario's clean electricity is getting far dirtier, producing millions of tonnes of climate-destabilizing carbon emissions and spewing toxic pollutants into the air in some of the most densely populated urban areas in the province.

"This will make air pollution worse, make climate pollution worse, and negatively affect Ontario's competitive advantage in having a clean grid," said Ontario Green Party Leader Mike Schreiner.

"And on top of that, because fossil gas is so much more expensive than solar, wind and water power, it's going to increase our electricity bills."

A deep dive into hour-by-hour generation data shows the province's 12 biggest gas plants operated nearly 12 hours a day, on average, every day this year.

The three GTA gas plants were turned on even more. The Portlands Energy Centre in Toronto, the Goreway Power Station in Brampton and the Halton Hills Generating Station have been in production for an average of 14 hours and 40 minutes a day.

This summer, when electricity demand was higher, the GTA plants were fired up more than 19 hours a day.

The Portlands plant, located on the waterfront in the heart of downtown Toronto, ran the most: nearly 21 hours a day, all summer long.

"I'm shocked how much these plants are running," said Keith Stewart, an energy strategist with Greenpeace Canada. "When they were being built, we were told they were supposed to only run around five per cent of the time. And they were just there to provide that last bit of security for the electricity system."

"Now they're actually the workhorses of the system, which is not what was promised."

It's been almost a decade since the last smog day in Toronto, so long that some may have forgotten about air quality concerns. But after a summer when the GTA was blanketed in forest fire smoke and children were kept indoors some days, the implications of running gas plants in the heart of Canada's biggest city are doubly clear: they add to local air pollution while also making climate change worse.

This is one of the reasons why clean, non-emitting, renewable energy has been identified as a top priority for addressing climate change. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the International Energy Agency, the Canadian Energy Regulator, the federal government and Ontario's Independent Electricity System Operator (IESO) have all said that achieving net zero emissions will require an all but-complete phaseout of fossil fuel-generated electricity.

The federal government is in the process of regulating that all electricity nationwide must be net zero by 2035. Yet Ontario hasn't built any new wind or solar energy since Premier Doug Ford was first elected in 2018. And the electricity generators already on the grid are emitting more pollution and more carbon as peaker plants now run virtually non-stop.

"These peaker plants are being used more than originally intended and that's not by accident. It's by design. It's a result of choices that this government has made to turn its back on clean energy and to instead go whole hog into more fossil fuels, using these existing plants more, extending their contracts longer, and also seeking to build new plants to add even more gas to the grid," said Keith Brooks, programs director at Environmental Defence.

Energy Minister Todd Smith declined to be interviewed for this story. In an emailed statement, he said he has committed to a 100 per cent clean grid, though did not say when it would be achieved. In the meantime, the use of gas will continue.

"Natural gas generation is our insurance policy that guarantees the lights stay on and prices stay down as we continue to refurbish our nuclear fleet and build out new technologies," Smith said in a statement.

Capital Power, the company that owns and operates the gas plants in Windsor and Brampton, said the company's statement that the new Windsor plant would run two per cent of the time refers to its capacity factor, a measurement of the plant's production versus its theoretical maximum output.

This "was and remains accurate," said spokesperson Katherine Perron.

Brampton's Goreway plant, however, is being used two and a half times more than it used to be, she said, due to "ongoing demand growth and nuclear refurbishments."

"Facilities like Goreway are only dispatched when market demands and conditions require their support so that all Ontarians can keep their lights on," she added.

Darius Sokal, a spokesperson for Atura Power, a subsidiary of the publicly owned Ontario Power Generation that runs the Portlands and Halton Hills plants, said: "Natural gas plays a critical role in Ontario's clean electricity system by reliably and affordably generating power during high demand periods. We comply with all provincial and federal emission standards."

THE PLANT NO ONE WANTED

Dubbed "the mistake by the lake" by opponents before it was even constructed, the Portlands gas plant was never welcome in downtown Toronto.

Paula Fletcher, the city councillor who has represented the ward that hosts the plant since 2003, said residents had fought hard to shut down two incinerators in the area because the toxic emissions were making them sick. Only two years later, the province announced that a new gas plant would be built, promising the return of more air pollution.

"This community tried to say this is not the right place for this particular plant and you should probably do something a little more efficient," said Fletcher.

One alternative proposal, which was endorsed by City Council, included a co-generation plant housed in the old Hearn Generating Station, which would provide power as well as steam to feed into Enwave's district heating system for the office towers downtown.

But the province overruled the city and went ahead with the Portlands electricity-only plan.

It was one of a fleet of gas plants commissioned by Queen's Park in the 2000s to replace the coal plants that were being phased out. Gas was supposed to be cleaner, and thanks to a burgeoning solar and wind industry, the new gas plants would only have to run as backup during peak times.

"We were told at the beginning that, don't worry, it's hardly ever going to run. So there'll be a minimal amount of emissions, a minimal amount of (air pollution). You won't notice it," Fletcher said.

While burning natural gas does produce less toxic air pollution than coal, its climate impact is now understood to be just as bad, if not worse.

That's because natural gas is mostly methane, a potent greenhouse gas. So leaks are far worse for the climate than emissions from combustion. Numerous studies have shown that "fugitive" leaks along the natural gas system - from the well to the pipeline to the furnace or gas plant - are far higher than previously thought.

Even without fugitive emissions, the Portlands gas plant is the largest single source of greenhouse gas emissions in Toronto. Emissions from the plant rose from 188,000 tonnes in 2017 to 618,000 tonnes in 2021, according to the federal government's national inventory of emissions.

Repeated calls to shut it down, or simply prevent its expansion, have gone unheeded. Toronto City Council has voted no fewer than three times against the plant, including twice this year just before the province announced an upgrade that would increase its output by nine per cent (a public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 5).

"What started off as a bad idea has become a really terrible idea on Toronto's waterfront," said Fletcher. "Nobody's watching this story and it is of great concern."

In the meantime, the Portlands plant has quietly ramped up its production, so that this summer it was only off for an average of three hours a day.

Former mayor David Miller, who is now managing director of the C40 Centre for City Climate Policy and Economy, staunchly opposed the Portlands plant before it was built, saying it was the wrong technology in the wrong place.

"On an issue as serious as this, I take no pleasure in being right," he told the Star. "I think it was a failure of imagination. It's a failure environmentally. It's a failure economically."

"The best case scenario for this plant was that you spent $730 million to only run a couple of hours a day in the summer, which is a ludicrous waste of money.

"The worst case scenario is it's being used far more, causing airborne pollutants that are directly linked to asthma and other health hazards and worsening the climate crisis. Both of those are completely wrong outcomes from a public policy perspective. We knew better then. We certainly know better now."

AIR POLLUTION

In 2014, Ontario became the first jurisdiction in the world to phase out coal-fired electricity, putting the province out ahead in an area that has become the linchpin to international efforts to curb climate change. But the Liberal government of then-premier Dalton McGuinty didn't get rid of coal because of climate change. They did it because air pollution had become a public health issue.

Studies linking the coal plants to smog and smog to thousands of premature deaths persuaded the government of the day to start the transition to clean electricity.

Unfortunately, while the coal plants are gone, the health concerns have not gone away.

"There's growing evidence about the health impacts of gas fired electricity plants," said Dr. Samantha Green, a family doctor at St. Michael's Hospital and president of the Canadian Association of Physicians for the Environment (CAPE).

"While they might be better than coal, they still have a significant health impact."

Gas plants produce nitrogen oxides, particulate matter and ground-level ozone, the main ingredient in smog.

Medical studies Green shared with the Star showed a link between living close to a gas plant and the development of asthma in children, exacerbation of asthma in people who already have it, as well as increased likelihood of preterm birth and emergency department visits.

One study found measurable health impacts in people living as far as 20 km away from a natural gas plant.

Draw a 20 km circle around the Portlands gas plant and you'll include virtually everyone who lives in Toronto. Add two more circles around the Brampton and Halton Hills plants and you'll add almost all of Brampton, Mississauga and Oakville, not to mention Milton, Bolton and large swaths of Vaughan.

All told, that's at least 4.5 million people who are facing adverse health effects from the increased use of the gas plants.

"Certainly, the highest impacts are actually felt by the people who are in proximity. But I think we don't have an answer to the question: How far away do you have to live before you are safe?" said Green.

A 2014 city report found that air pollution is responsible for 1,300 premature deaths in Toronto each year. A 2021 Health Canada study pegged the number at 6,600 province-wide.

"I don't think people are aware of the health impact, frankly," said NDP MPP Peter Tabuns, who has represented the riding around the Portlands plant since 2006. "They were far more aware when coal was the issue because you could see it. It's not as visible now, but clearly it's having substantial health impacts."

A 2012 report prepared by the city's environment office found "pollutants such as ozone, nitrogen dioxides, and particulate matter are found at levels that are known to have an adverse impact on health," in the wards immediately adjacent to the Portlands Energy Centre. But modelling performed at the time concluded the gas plant contributed "only insignificantly" to nitrogen oxides levels.

Fletcher, the local councillor, said it's time for the city to test the air in downtown Toronto again, now that we know the plant is running 86 per cent of the time.

MORE GAS PLANTS, RUNNING MORE OFTEN

Last year, in response to the 34 municipalities that passed resolutions calling for the phaseout of gas power, the province's electricity system regulator put out a report plotting a path to complete decarbonization.

It was a disappointment to climate activists and renewable energy proponents alike.

According to the IESO, continued use of gas is necessary, and in fact, more is needed. Phasing out gas would require a colossal investment of $400 billion and would take more than 20 years to accomplish.

It's a conclusion that has been disputed by several other expert reports, including one from RBC, which said no new gas plants are needed to meet electricity demand.

The IESO's logic is that gas plants are one-of-a-kind.

"Ontario's natural gas fleet is capable of providing continuous, flexible energy year round and under all weather conditions, and there is currently no like-for-like replacement," the IESO's Pathways to Decarbonization report states.

No sooner was the report tabled than the provincial government put out a call for 1,500 megawatts of new gas generation.

Queen's Park also issued a call for grid-scale batteries, which can serve the same role as gas plants, but only for four hours at a time. (This means they could replace true peaker plants, but cannot fill the expanded role gas plants currently serve, running far longer.)

There's no indication that new renewable energy - wind and solar - will be built any time soon. Despite being the cheapest source of electricity in history, Ontario has opted to spend billions on a new generation of nuclear plants instead.

Despite this spring's announcements of both small and full-size nuclear plants, the province will still be facing a serious shortfall of generation when the Pickering nuclear plant shuts down - long before the new plants are ready.

And the plan is to make up that shortfall by using the gas plants even more.

Projections produced by the IESO show that gas plants provincewide, which currently operate just under six hours a day, will rapidly increase their runtime to more than 19 hours a day in 2026.

But these averages, which cover 47 gas plants, small and large, scattered across the province, mask the fact that three of the biggest gas plants, nestled among houses and businesses in the GTA, are already used far more.

BUSINESSES WANT CLEAN ELECTRICITY

This summer, the provincial government blanketed TV, radio and even YouTube with ads proclaiming "the future is electric."

The message celebrated the return of auto manufacturing to Ontario, in the form of an industry-wide transition to electric vehicles (EVs).

The economic boost provided by these blue collar jobs has been a bright spot for Ford's government, prompting a change in attitude toward EVs, which started out as an object of scorn, as the premier cancelled purchase subsidies and ripped out charging stations.

Part of the reason battery and EV plants are setting up in Ontario is because of the province's clean electricity, a legacy of the coal-phaseout.

That clean electricity advantage was cited by Ford at last year's opening of the EV delivery truck assembly line in Ingersoll. Energy Minister Todd Smith has routinely said clean electricity underpins Ontario's attractiveness to business investment.

But it's a head start that risks being squandered now that the province is leaning so heavily on gas.

"Companies want to be able to say that they're cutting their greenhouse gas emissions. And what is being done by the Ford government is a substantial ramp up," said the NDP's Tabuns.

"We're seeing Ontario on track to emissions that will wipe out 60 per cent of the greenhouse gas reduction impact from shutting down coal. It's as if we've gone through that whole exercise to reduce our carbon footprint, and they've decided to largely wipe it out."

Meanwhile, the federal government has tabled a draft of its Clean Electricity Regulations, which promise net-zero electricity nationwide by 2035.

While the federal regulations will allow for some natural gas to remain for "peaking" and "emergency backup" purposes, an independent analysis found that many of Ontario's plants were currently operating 10 times more than they would be allowed to under the new rules.

This leaves Ontario's gas plant expansion plan with serious issues to resolve, said Environmental Defence's Brooks.

The province is trying to convince power providers to build plants that may be illegal to operate in 12 years, he said, and in order to do so, they're offering guaranteed payment, even if the plants shut down. What's more, they're in a hurry, Brooks said, because it appears any plants built before 2025 will be grandfathered in and allowed to operate until 2045.

"Ontarians are getting a raw deal either way. Either we're getting more gas plants, more emissions and more contributions to climate change, or we're paying for gas plants that aren't even running, which is going to cost us," he said.

"Ontarians are going to be on the hook paying billions of dollars for plants that we really don't want, don't need and shouldn't be using in the climate crisis."

PUSHBACK

The call for new gas plants has been out for almost a year. But only three sites have been announced. Taken together, the three prospective plants would only provide about a third of the amount of new gas called for, leaving the province scrambling to attract more proposals.

Last month, there was another setback. Thorold, a community in Niagara Region, voted to reject a new plant in their community over air pollution concerns.

The Ford government has taken notice, conscious of the fact that community outrage against gas plants helped bring down one of his predecessors.

"There's a reason why people in Mississauga and Oakville fought against gas plants like a decade or more ago. And it wasn't because of climate change. It was because they were concerned about the impact to air quality in their communities," said Brooks.

Or as Don Morley, a lifelong resident of Thorold who lives beside the existing plant, said:

"It was difficult for me, but I figure I had no choice but to step up and voice a concern that affects all of us," he told city council before the vote.

"There are many victims out there. Victims I shouldn't say, but citizens that deserve better."

Toronto City Council has voted no fewer than three times against the plant, including twice this year just before the province announced an upgrade that would increase its output by nine per cent (a public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 5).

In 2014, Ontario became the first jurisdiction in the world to phase out coal-fired electricity, putting the province out ahead in an area that has become the linchpin to international efforts to curb climate change. But the Liberal government of then-premier Dalton McGuinty didn't get rid of coal because of climate change. They did it because air pollution had become a public health issue.

Studies linking the coal plants to smog and smog to thousands of premature deaths persuaded the government of the day to start the transition to clean electricity.

Unfortunately, while the coal plants are gone, the health concerns have not gone away.

"There's growing evidence about the health impacts of gas fired electricity plants," said Dr. Samantha Green, a family doctor at St. Michael's Hospital and president of the Canadian Association of Physicians for the Environment (CAPE).

"While they might be better than coal, they still have a significant health impact."

Medical studies Green shared with the Star showed a link between living close to a gas plant and the development of asthma in children, exacerbation of asthma in people who already have it, as well as increased likelihood of preterm birth and emergency department visits.

One study found measurable health impacts in people living as far as 20 km away from a natural gas plant.

Draw a 20 km circle around the Portlands gas plant and you'll include virtually everyone who lives in Toronto. Add two more circles around the Brampton and Halton Hills plants and you'll add almost all of Brampton, Mississauga and Oakville, not to mention Milton, Bolton and large swaths of Vaughan.

Last year, in response to the 34 municipalities that passed resolutions calling for the phaseout of gas power, the province's electricity system regulator put out a report plotting a path to complete decarbonization.

According to the IESO, continued use of gas is necessary, and in fact, more is needed. Phasing out gas would require a colossal investment of $400 billion and would take more than 20 years to accomplish.

The message celebrated the return of auto manufacturing to Ontario, in the form of an industry-wide transition to electric vehicles (EVs).
